channel.title: Language - Digg
channel.description: Language on Digg: the best articles, videos, tweets, and original content that the web is talking about right now

item.title: Prolonged Isolation Can Lead To The Creation Of New Accents
item.description: Social distancing might not entirely change the way we talk, but a Mars expedition might do the trick.

item.title: The Many Languages Missing From The Internet
item.description: English and a handful of other languages dominate the internet, but this is leaving indigenous cultures without a voice online. Now they are fighting back.

item.title: Let A Star Cast Of Actors Help You Brush Up On British Slang
item.description: Learn all the British, Scottish and Welsh "ism's" from Rachel Weisz, Simon Pegg, Emma Thompson and so many others.

item.title: 500-Year-Old Manuscript Contains One Of Earliest Known Uses Of The 'F-Word'
item.description: The Bannatyne Manuscript is an anthology of some 400 medieval Scottish poems.

item.title: Why The Language Spoken In 'Animal Crossing' Is Different In Japan
item.description: Here's why Nintendo decided to localize Animalese, the fictional language spoken in "Animal Crossing."

item.title: Grammarly Premium Makes A Lot Of Mistakes
item.description: I've used Grammarly for as long as I can remember (and my memory stretches back at least two months, maybe even longer), and I can confirm that the AI overlords are not beyond human grammar-checkers just yet

item.title: A Brief History Of Word Games
item.description: When I began to research the history of crosswords for my recent book on the subject, I was sort of shocked to discover that they weren't invented until 1913.

item.title: Movies Should Bring Back The Dramatic 'Damn,' Dammit
item.description: A good, dramatic "damn" is much better than half an expletive cut off by a sound effect.

item.title: Why Do Americans Use The Word 'Like' In The Middle Of Sentences?
item.description: How did valspeak permeate into, like, the American way of talking?

item.title: Free Speech Isn't A Free Pass For Privacy Violations
item.description: Classifying something as "speech" is only the first step in First Amendment analysis.

item.title: Computers Have Gotten Eerily Good At Mimicking The Way We Speak
item.description: A.I. generated text is getting really good — what does that mean for the future of the internet?

item.title: Why Do We Keep Coming Up With Stupid Names For Dating Trends?
item.description: From "haunting" and "orbiting" to "cloaking" and "whelming," everyone wants to coin the next ghosting, but few of these trendy dating terms really catch on.

item.title: Why Air Supply Changed The Lyrics To 'All Out Of Love' For American Listeners
item.description: The mellow duo Air Supply found success in the 1980s thanks to their easy-listening love songs. But one lyric was so strange it had to be revised.

item.title: 'Bad' English Is Part Of My Korean American Heritage
item.description: Once a source of shame, but I now say it proudly: bad English is my heritage.

item.title: Multilingual Translator Has To Guess Strangers' Languages Blindfolded
item.description: While he may not have always gotten the language exactly right, the translator has some great instincts when it comes to pinpointing a general region where the language might come from.

item.title: Why Do Corporations Speak The Way They Do?
item.description: The pernicious spread of corporatespeak — or garbage language — which permeates the ways we think of our jobs and shapes our identities as workers.

item.title: A Fascinating Diagram Breaking Down The 100 Most-Spoken Languages In The World
item.description: Mandarin and English are the most-spoken languages in the world, but the fuller picture is far more complicated and more interesting.

item.title: What Sentences Are Incomprehensible To Computers?
item.description: Despite all the progress we've made in technology, computers still lag in making sense of what we're telling them.

item.title: What Is The Hardest Language In The World To Lipread?
item.description: There's a whole lot we don't know vision and speech perception.

item.title: How Babies Learn Languages So Quickly
item.description: Learning a language is child's play, but linguists are still trying to understand how children do it so easily.

item.title: Polyglot Gives His Tips On How To Learn A Language As Quickly As Possible
item.description: Don't just memorize words. Memorize patterns of speech. Oh, and learn a language like a baby would.

item.title: The Strange Quest To Crack The Voynich Code
item.description: Why are so many scholars and scientists obsessed with deciphering a bizarre, illustrated 600-year old manuscript?

item.title: If You Can't Beat Them, Call Them Trumpian
item.description: Ireland's ascendent Sinn Féin party is nothing like Trump, but that hasn't stopped critics from levying an increasingly banal attack.

item.title: Comedy's Toughest Gig
item.description: Once he noticed an American Sign Language interpreter parked close to him, Robin Williams, like many other comedians, had a habit of getting crude with them.

item.title: A History Of Simlish, The Language That Defined The Sims
item.description: As The Sims celebrates its 20th anniversary, we look back at one of its defining traits: Simlish, a made-up language that helped players better connect to their in-game creations.

item.title: The Movies With The Most F-Words, Visualized
item.description: Here's a chart of movies that gave zero f*cks about dropping the F-bomb again and again.

item.title: Do You Think In Words?
item.description: When you are aware of your own consciousness — meaning your own individual scattershot thoughts, like what to make for lunch, whether to cross the street, or when it's time to go hit the pillow — what do you hear?
item.kicker: QUICK, DON'T THINK ANY WORDS RIGHT NOW

item.title: Seemingly Clueless American Orders Food In Perfect Chinese, Shocking Patrons And Staff
item.description: Xiaoma astounds people at this restaurant in Chinatown by speaking both perfect Mandarin and Cantonese.
item.kicker: DID HE JUST SAY WHAT I THINK HE SAID?

item.title: These People Who Live In A Remote Village In Turkey Communicate Using Whistles
item.description: The fascinating kuş dili or bird language allows speakers to communicate long distances.

item.title: How Does Garth Greenwell Make Such Wonderful Sentences?
item.description: Discussions of prose style very seldom concern themselves with the actual grammar of sentences. We think of grammar as strict and harsh, something punitive, prescriptive. And yet grammar is the key to much of what makes sentences sing.

item.title: The Alphabets At Risk Of Extinction
item.description: It isn't just languages that are endangered: dozens of alphabets around the world are at risk. And they could have even more to tell us.

item.title: Guessing Names Based On What They Start With
item.description: Put in your sex, the decade you were born, and start entering your name below. I'll try to guess your full name before you're done.

item.title: The Language Used Only by Lake Kivu's Fishermen
item.description: As they paddle out each night, they sing in a disappearing language.

item.title: Why Are Presidential Speeches Getting Dumber?
item.description: The reading levels of American presidential speeches have plunged over the years. Are presidents dumbing them down for their listeners?

item.title: Is This The Most Powerful Word In The English Language?
item.description: The most commonly-used word in English might only have three letters — but it packs a punch.

item.title: Why We Love Untranslatable Words
item.description: Goya. A small word, but one that contains multitudes. It is one of those mythic beasts, the "untranslatables," the foreign words that supposedly lack any equivalent in English. Lists of them spread virally online. But for now, let us examine goya.

item.title: How The CIA, FBI And Secret Service Come Up With Their Code Names
item.description: Rawhide, Tumbler, Smurfette, Mogul — what's the secret behind the coolest (and weirdest) White House code names?
item.kicker: GOT A CODE WEIRD SITUATION HERE

item.title: A Translation Crisis At The Border
item.description: For migrants who speak Mayan languages, a grassroots group of interpreters is often their only hope for receiving asylum.

item.title: The Outer Fringes Of Our Language: A Conversation With Werner Herzog
item.description: Robert Harrison speaks to Werner Herzog about his devotion to books.

item.title: We Learned To Write The Way We Talk
item.description:
Ironic Capitals and strettttchedddd
out words have allowed us to communicate our feelings in writing like never before.

item.title: Teaching A Computer Chinese Made It Excellent At English
item.description: By one measure, Baidu's natural-language algorithm understands English better than any other.

item.title: What Does Clout Mean?
item.description: How did a word once reserved for union bosses get co-opted by anybody with a viral tweet?
item.kicker: JUST A FANCY WAY TO SAY 'POPULAR'

item.title: Do We Even Still Need The Question Mark
item.description: Question mark rules: is it ungrammatical to drop the question mark when texting?

item.title: Why North Carolina Is The Most Linguistically Diverse State
item.description: The Tar Heel State is the intertidal zone of the linguistic South: Overwhelming forces wash in and out, but weird, fascinating little tide pools remain.

item.title: How To Save A Dying Language
item.description: The Hawaiian language nearly went extinct. Now it's being taught in dozens of immersion schools.

item.title: A Linguist Asks: What Might Baby Yoda's First Words Be?
item.description: Even if Baby Yoda lived with other Yoda-style speakers in the past, it's still doubtful that he would have typical Yoda syntax.

item.title: Continue Using Apostrophes Correctly, We Beg of You
item.description: John Richards, one of the most ardent defenders of the correct use of the apostrophe, is giving up. We have to keep the cause alive.

item.title: In Praise Of Badly Dubbed Movies
item.description: "When I decided to binge watch several dozen spaghetti westerns, I didn't expect the dubbing to be one of the best parts. It was."
item.kicker: VOULEZ-VOUS VOIR UN FILM AVEC MOI CE SOIR?

item.title: The Most Common Last Names In Every Country, Mapped
item.description: When it comes to English-speaking countries, the popular conception is that Smith is the most common last name, but is that conception really true?

item.title: Stop Using Word Clouds Without The Context
item.description: Word clouds don't show the relations between the words, losing the context.
item.kicker: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MISINTERPRETATION
